narrative.title: Xiii Corps - 1943Q2
narrative.situation: British Corps (Infantry) deployed in North Africa during 1943Q2.
narrative.objectives: XIII Corps' final North Africa operations (Q2 1943) limited to April 1943: Battle of Wadi Akarit (5-6 April) where 50th Infantry Division successfully attacked central sector, crossing anti-tank ditch and securing objectives with light casualties. Corps withdrawn from front line 19 April after Wadi Akarit success, relieved by 56th London Division. Road march to Alexandria began 24 April. Tunisia Campaign ended 13 May 1943 with Axis surrender (250,000 prisoners). May-June: Corps spent in Egypt conducting rest, refit, replacement training, and amphibious operations preparation for Operation Husky (Sicily invasion, July 1943). XIII Corps to land in Sicily with 5th and 50th Infantry Divisions under Lieutenant-General Dempsey.
narrative.axis_objective: Hold current positions and prevent Allied breakthrough.
narrative.allied_objective: Advance and neutralize Axis defensive positions.

weather.terrain: April: Wadi Akarit defensive line (coastal sector, mountainous inland terrain). May-June: Egyptian training areas near Alexandria (coastal plain, desert training grounds). Preparing for Sicily amphibious operations.
environmental_challenges: April: Final Tunisia battles - Wadi Akarit coastal/mountain terrain challenges
May-June: Rising desert heat during Egypt training (28-32°C)
Transition from desert warfare to amphibious operations training
Sicily preparation required beach assault tactics development
Mediterranean coastal training for amphibious landings

air_support.note: No theater air summary available for this quarter

special_rules: Successful assault operations (Wadi Akarit, light casualties)
